items.message: River levels are due to rise at the Fosseway and Great Somerford gauges, with flood warnings possible Tuesday morning. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. Further rain is forecast Monday afternoon and into Tuesday. River levels are expected to rise further in response to this rain. We are closely monitoring the situation . Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Tidal conditions are expected to improve and no flooding is expected. Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow, 27th January 2026. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

The risk of flooding remains. Flooding is possible on 27 January 2026 and remains possible over the next few days. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road and Sileby Mill road, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes. Rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels remain high at the Pillings Lock Gauge and will continue to be so over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water & avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated after 09:00 on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: High river levels this evening may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 26 January 2026. This information is correct as of 15:30 on Monday 26 January 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 17cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 16cm of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 08:00 on Tuesday 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The river level at Huish Episcopi is currently 8.63m and dropping. The drain level at Huish Episcopi is stable at 8.11m. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.

Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once river spillways stop running.

Monday morning will be dry, however a period of heavy and persistent rain is forecast from mid-afternoon onwards. This will continue overnight and into Tuesday morning. River and moor levels are expected to rise in response to this.

We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 1PM on 27/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High river levels overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 26 January 2026 .

We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.64m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.69m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m.

For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels.
We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and temporary pumps are also being deployed to Northmoor. 

Monday morning will be dry, however a period of heavy and persistent rain is forecast from mid-afternoon onwards. This will continue overnight and into Tuesday morning. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 1PM on 27/01/2026 or as the situation changes.

Forecast total high tide levels are 1.90mAOD and 2.14mAOD respectively, which is up to 1.1 metres above tide table level.  Gale force 7 south to south-easterly winds and offshore wave heights up to 2.5m are forecast over the high tides.

Coastal conditions should ease for Tuesday evening's high tide. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Levels remain high at the Stinsford and East Stoke gauges following prolonged rainfall and high groundwater. We are closely monitoring the situation . Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Washford River, riverside properties from Kingsbridge to Lower Roadwater
items.message:
The level on the Washford River remains high and is expected to rise further today in response to forecast rainfall.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Washford River, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. Areas at risk include properties in Roadwater and roads in Kingsbridge.

Monday morning will be dry, however a period of heavy and persistent rain is forecast from mid-afternoon onwards. This will continue overnight and into Tuesday morning. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely and Field Teams are clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. 

Act on your flood plan if you have one and check that any flood resistance and resilience equipment you may have is operational.

This message will be updated by 1PM on 27/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

Heavy rain falling in the area will continue overnight.

Properties and low lying areas will start to flood from around 04:00AM on Tuesday. The main areas of concern are Hele, Silverton Mills, Rewe, the A396 at Stoke Canon and and roads at Columbjohn and Westcott. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. 

River levels are forecast to be at their highest between 09:00AM and 14:00PM. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car Start acting on your flood plan if you have one 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon from Salisbury to Ringwood
items.message: This is a flood warning update. High river levels and forecast heavy rain later today and overnight are expected to cause flooding. Flooding is expected on 26 January 2026 .  Locations most affected will be Areas most at risk include areas in Britford, Charlton All Saints, Downton and Fordingbridge in close proximity to the River Avon. Rivers are still rising due to recent persistent rainfall.  This rain falling on saturated ground will likely raise levels further.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels .  Activate any flood protection products you may have .  This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.64m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.69m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m.

For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels.

We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and temporary pumps are also being deployed to Northmoor. 

Monday morning will be dry, however a period of heavy and persistent rain is forecast from mid-afternoon onwards. This will continue overnight and into Tuesday morning. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 1PM on 27/01/2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 27 January 2026 from 13:00, as a lot of rain is forecast (35mm). 
If as much rain falls as predicted, flooding could affect fields, roads, and gardens along the River Lox, including isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. From 17:00 on 27/01/2026 flooding could approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Rain should ease by 13:00 on 27/01/2026. River levels could peak higher than 22/01/2026. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 06:00 on 28/01/2026, but the river could be higher than normal until the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst. 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Carisbrooke and Hunny Hill on the Lukely Brook
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 from 05:00, as a lot of rain (24mm) fell on Tuesday. 
Flooding will affect property at the bottom of Castle Street. The Aquatics Centre at Vicarage Walk near Foxes Road will also flood. Water levels will be very high at Caesars Road and Old Westminster Lane, and the river could come out of bank flooding roads and parked cars. Rain is forecast to continue until 10:00 27/01/2026 with showers forecast this afternoon. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce in Hunny Hill by 13:00 27/01/2026. 
We are checking rivers for blockages . 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Monday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 26 January 2026 as a lot of rain is forecast from later today (35mm). 
Flooding is affecting low lying land, roads, cycle tracks and footpaths close to the river. Flooding could affect Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. A similar event to 21/01/26 is forecast later today (Monday 26/01/26) and overnight. This will lead to an increase in  flood risk. River levels in the Lower Eastern Yar may not fall until later this week, as drainage will be impeded by the tides entering their Neap cycle. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and operating Bembridge sluices. 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Rising groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding.  Flooding is expected from 19th January 2026 onwards.  Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Iwerne Minster.  Further rain is forecast over the next few days. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, please take care when driving.  We are closely monitoring the situation .  If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts Please do not drive through floodwater as this may cause bow waves.  This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 2 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently high at our Draycott borehole in the Upper Og Valley. We expect levels to rise over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

The forecast is for a wet few days followed by an unsettled period. Depending on the rainfall received, we may see localised groundwater impacts. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are closely monitoring rainfall and groundwater levels.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Take particular care when driving through flood water both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. 

This message will be updated by 12:00 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Pimperne Brook
items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 24 January 2026 onwards. 
The groundwater level at the Iwerne Hill Farm borehole is rising in response to recent heavy rainfall and will continue to do so as more rain is forecast. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk . 
This message will be updated by 11:41AM on 31 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.64m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.69m. Cutts Road and New Road are closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 is also closed.

For road closure information please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/

We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and are deploying temporary pumps to Northmoor pumping station. The River Tone level is currently too high for pumping at Currymoor. We will commence pumping at Currymoor and operate the Parrett Relief Channel once river levels allow.

Monday morning will be dry, however a period of heavy and persistent rain is forecast from mid-afternoon onwards. This will continue overnight and into Tuesday morning. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks and spillways. Please do not walk, cycle or drive through flood water.

items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from Wednesday, 28/01/2026, following a wet January 2026. 
Flooding could affect the electricity sub station in Rectory Lane, Meonstoke. The Winterbourne will begin to flow across Rectory Lane and behind the Buck's Head Pub. Tomorrow (27/01/2026), Storm Chandra will pass through the south of England, bringing up to 50mm of rain to Hampshire. A combination of high river flows and groundwater may affect a couple of cellars of properties on West Meon High Street and Lynch Lane. Lighter rain is forecast from Wednesday (28/01/2026) to Friday (30/01/2026). Groundwater levels at the borehole at Pound Lane, Meonstoke will continue rising through this week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 30 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding this morning. 
Flooding is expected from the early hours of 27 January 2026 . 
Heavy rain falling in the area will continue throughout the day.

Properties and low lying areas will start to flood from around 4:30AM on Tuesday. The main areas of concern are Hemyock, Whitehall Mill, Coldharbour, Willand Factory Cottages and Skinners Farm, Hayne Barton Cottages and Venn Farm. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. 

River levels are likely to remain high throughout the morning. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car . Activate any flood protection products you may have. 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 . 
River levels are remaining high on the River Bride. Areas most at risk include High Street, Mill Street, Manor Farm and The Rookery in Burton Bradstock. Rain is forecast to continue overnight and into the morning. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals Don't put yourself or others at risk. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Char at Dolphins River Caravan Park
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 . 
River levels are rising rapidly on the River Char due to tonight’s heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include Dolphins River Park. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals Don't put yourself or others at risk. 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 . 
River levels are rising rapidly on the River Winniford due to heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include North Chideock, Fairfax and Main Street Chideock. Flooding is expected at North Chideock, Fairfax and Main Street Chideock. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded Don't put yourself or others at risk. 
This message will be updated by 4:30PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 . 
River levels are rising rapidly on the Swan Brook due to heavy rainfall. River levels are expected to remain high on the Swan Brook. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Swan Brook, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Victoria Ave, Kings Rd, Chestnut Mew, Church Hill, Springfield Rd, Cornwall Rd, Commerical Rd, Station Rd, Institute Rd, The Square, Shore Rd, High St and Parade in Swanage. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties Don't put yourself or others at risk. 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.
